conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the system to determine the pressure exerted by sphere D on spheres A, B, and C.
Sphere D is in static equilibrium, so the net force acting on it is zero.
Forces on sphere D: gravitational force \( F_g = mg \) downward and normal forces \( N_A, N_B, N_C \) from spheres A, B, and C.
Due to symmetry, normal forces from spheres A, B, and C on sphere D are equal: \( N_A = N_B = N_C = N \).
The gravitational force \( mg \) is balanced by the vertical components of the normal forces.
The centers of spheres A, B, and C form an equilateral triangle with side length \( 2r \).
The height of the triangle formed by A, B, and C is \( \sqrt{3}r \), and the vertical distance from D to the plane is \( r \).
The vertical component of each normal force is \( N \cos \theta \), and total upward force is \( 3N \cos \theta \).
Set \( 3N \cos \theta = mg \) and solve for \( N \): \( N = \frac{mg \sqrt{3}}{3} \).
The contact area is a circle with radius \( r \), so area \( A = \pi r^2 \).
The pressure exerted by sphere D on each of the bottom spheres A, B, and C is \( P = \frac{mg \sqrt{3}}{3\pi r^2} \).
